title: Labour brutally slap down 'fantasy' plan to make John Bercow caretaker PM

Labour have vehemently slapped down a plan to make John Bercow caretaker Prime Minister to stop a no-deal Brexit .

According to the Sunday Times, MPs discussed an eyebrow-raising plan to install the Commons Speaker as head of a "government of national unity" - despite dividing MPs with his approach to Parliament.

But it came just hours after Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell made clear he would accept no one but Jeremy Corbyn as an interim PM.

And today, Shadow Attorney General Shami Chakrabarti branded the plan a "fantasy".

She told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show: "We are now getting into almost fantasy football. I think it's unlikely, I really really do."

(Image: JESSICA TAYLOR/UK PARLIAMENT/HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

Baroness Chakrabarti added: "What we need to concentrate on is getting no deal ruled out... and then to head for a general election

"I just think we’re getting into a level of fantasy around these various permutations of unity governments. It’s just not realistic."

The plan to install Speaker Bercow as a caretaker PM was briefed by unknown MPs today to the Sunday Times.

Opposition MPs are seeking to install a temporary unity government if Boris Johnson - who has a majority below minus 40 - loses a vote of no-confidence in his government.

(Image: PA)

Under the law, if the government loses a confidence vote, another group of MPs can take power within 14 days if they command a majority in the Commons.

If there's no rival group, a general election is triggered.

Having a temporary Prime Minister would prevent Boris Johnson forcing an election immediately and using the power vacuum to ram through a no-deal Brexit.

But opposition MPs are split over who that unity figure should be. Labour insist it must be Jeremy Corbyn - but the Lib Dems insist he is not the right candidate to unify the Commons.

(Image: PA)

John McDonnell yesterday said he would accept no one but Jeremy Corbyn as a caretaker Prime Minister.

Asked if he'd accept an alternative Mr McDonnell told La Repubblica: "There's no way we would accept that.

"The just normal process is that the major party takes over. And I would expect that as well. And the majority of the opposition parties accept that.

"The SNP , the Greens, the Change UK have accepted that. The Liberal Democrats for their own purposes are holding out at the moment. I don't think that will last very long”.

(Image: Dan Kitwood)

A source close to the Shadow Chancellor confirmed his view had not changed since the Bercow plan came forward.

An election now cannot be held before October 31 under the current law - because it needs a 25 working day countdown.

Labour is demanding an election but only once it is certain Brexit will be delayed beyond October 31 to stop no-deal.

Baroness Chakrabarti said once that has been complied with, there should be a general election "certainly this side of Christmas".
description: The Speaker was mooted as the possible head of a 'government of national unity' - but Labour gave the idea short shrift
